inlineContent.text: A
is the foundation of an application. It wraps some
low-level platform-specific services and is intended to act as the
foundation for higher-level application classes such as
or
. In general, you should not use
this class outside of a higher level framework.
provides convenient life-cycle management by maintaining
a “use count” for the primary application instance. The use count can
be changed using [method
] and
[method
]. If it drops to zero, the application
exits. Higher-level classes such as
employ the use count
to ensure that the application stays alive as long as it has any opened
windows.
Another feature that
(optionally) provides is process
uniqueness. Applications can make use of this functionality by
providing a unique application ID. If given, only one application
with this ID can be running at a time per session. The session
concept is platform-dependent, but corresponds roughly to a graphical
desktop login. When your application is launched again, its
arguments are passed through platform communication to the already
running program. The already running instance of the program is
called the “primary instance”; for non-unique applications this is
always the current instance. On Linux, the D-Bus session bus
is used for communication.
The use of
differs from some other commonly-used
uniqueness libraries (such as libunique) in important ways. The
application is not expected to manually register itself and check
if it is the primary instance. Instead, the
function of a
should do very little more than instantiating the
application instance, possibly connecting signal handlers, then
calling [method
]. All checks for uniqueness are done
internally. If the application is the primary instance then the
startup signal is emitted and the mainloop runs. If the application
is not the primary instance then a signal is sent to the primary
instance and [method
] promptly returns. See the code
examples below.
If used, the expected form of an application identifier is the
same as that of a
Examples include:
For details on valid application identifiers, see [func
On Linux, the application identifier is claimed as a well-known bus name
on the user’s session bus. This means that the uniqueness of your
application is scoped to the current session. It also means that your
application may provide additional services (through registration of other
object paths) at that bus name. The registration of these object paths
should be done with the shared GDBus session bus. Note that due to the
internal architecture of GDBus, method calls can be dispatched at any time
(even if a main loop is not running). For this reason, you must ensure that
any object paths that you wish to register are registered before
attempts to acquire the bus name of your application (which happens in
[method
]). Unfortunately, this means that you cannot
use [property
] to decide if you want to register
object paths.
also implements the [iface
] and [iface
interfaces and lets you easily export actions by adding them with
[method
]. When invoking an action by calling
[method
] on the application, it is always
invoked in the primary instance. The actions are also exported on
the session bus, and GIO provides the [class
] wrapper to
conveniently access them remotely. GIO provides a [class
] wrapper
for remote access to exported [class
Note: Due to the fact that actions are exported on the session bus,
using
parameters is not supported, since D-Bus does not support
types.
There is a number of different entry points into a
via ‘Activate’ (i.e. just starting the application)
via ‘Open’ (i.e. opening some files)
by handling a command-line
via activating an action
The [signal[Application](//documentation/gio/application/onstartup(flags:handler:)] signal lets you handle the application
initialization for all of these in a single place.
Regardless of which of these entry points is used to start the
application,
passes some ‘platform data’ from the
launching instance to the primary instance, in the form of a
[struct[Variant](//documentation/glib/variant] dictionary mapping strings to variants. To use platform
data, override the [vfunc
] or
[vfunc
] virtual functions
in your
subclass. When dealing with
[class
] objects, the platform data is
directly available via [method
[method
] and
[method
As the name indicates, the platform data may vary depending on the
operating system, but it always includes the current directory (key
), and optionally the environment (ie the set of environment
variables and their values) of the calling process (key
The environment is only added to the platform data if the
flag is set.
subclasses
can add their own platform data by overriding the
[vfunc
] virtual function. For instance,
adds startup notification data in this way.
To parse commandline arguments you may handle the
[signal[Application](//documentation/gio/application/oncommandline(flags:handler:)] signal or override the
[vfunc
] virtual function, to parse them in
either the primary instance or the local instance, respectively.

, see
For an example of using actions with

For an example of using extra D-Bus hooks with

The
protocol exposes the methods and properties of an underlying
instance.
The default implementation of these can be found in the protocol extension below.
For a concrete class that implements these methods and properties, see
Alternatively, use
as a lighweight,
reference if you already have an instance you just want to use.

is the core class for application support.
represents the contents of a menu — an ordered list of
menu items. The items are associated with actions, which can be
activated through them. Items can be grouped in sections, and may
have submenus associated with them. Both items and sections usually
have some representation data, such as labels or icons. The type of
the associated action (ie whether it is stateful, and what kind of
state it has) can influence the representation of the item.
